I am not a native english speaker either, but this game helped me alot in terms of learning english.
When I started playing league 4 years ago, my english was pretty shitty, no joke. I never took any english classes besides the one at school, which was really bad when I think about it now. Now I can proudly say my english is so good, I can communicate with people around the whole world (in texting only, my pronouncements are shitty) and I'm really happy about it.
The fact that everyone communicates in english makes it so much easier to learn the language and understand things you couldn't before.
Who knew League chat of all places would actually teach you something worthwhile? Especially in EUW
Oh I learned a lot from the game, not only did I improve my english by far, I also learned that a negative mindset will never bring you far and much more.

On the negative mindset: League is probably the only thing in my life where I actively try to not be negative. 

I don't know why. Maybe I've had one too many games where I realized the impossible can happen.
It only takes that one Xpeke or 4-man win and you're inspired forever. Godspeed Ralanr.
I've had enough Sion Xpeke to never say die.

>
> Isnt NA home to hundreds of ethnicities with different languages?

Good point!

Not really... English is the primary language in the US and Canada, the US has a decently large Spanish-speaking population, and Canada has a small French-speaking population. 

Other than that, there's just a few Native American reservations where some of the older folks might still know their  ancestral language, but everyone uses English except for the occasional tribal ceremony. And there's a few pockets in coastal regions where large numbers of Asian immigrants live together ("chinatowns" and the like). But, that's it.

Nearly everyone in NA's primary language is English and, if it isn't their primary, they almost always speak it decently as a secondary (especially considering the gamer demographic were talking about).

Yes. Exactly. I'm sick of people saying "the U.S. is diverse in it's languages and ethnicities" but at this point it really isn't. It's a mix of everything that's become mostly homogeneous. Even cultural pockets like chinatowns usually have huge amounts of American/U.S. culture bled in.

It's a false analogy.

The McDonald's workers are by contract meant to know and speak the official language of whatever, because they're providing a service as a business, which makes them by obligation meant to know the official language and speak it as a default option to their customers (secondary options would be applied if communication can not be established too, such as grabbing someone who can speak the customer's language from the back to the counter).

But no one is providing service that's contracted by a business to play with their teammates, so they are under no obligation to speak the official language.

The correct analogy is that: There is a community game of whatever where everyone is free to join, and this guy comes in while speaking in a non-official language, and everyone is looking at him funny until one guy tells him "for the love of god, speak English".

Do you think it's justified?

Again, unless the teamwork is seriously being crippled, or that there is this dickbag who purposely goes to sabotage the team communication, otherwise there is literally nothing wrong if you don't speak the official language of whatever as long as there are using work-arounds like pings, or at least they follow the rest of the team.

If you have to have a team that all speak in the same language for clarify purposes, you can simply organise a premade. Solo queues are meant for solo'ers, it's never meant to have perfect communication and coordination.

I am saying that that's what it is like. 

There is no "correct analogy" because there could be infinite analogies for the same thing.

Generally, if this is happening, it's because there is a dickbag who purposely does it to sabotage the teams communication. When you ask them to speak english, they say "no, you speak french" or some garbage saying that you should apeal to the vast minority of the NA playerbase.

I personally have never come into contact with anyone on the NA servers that can't speak English if they speak french. 100% of the time my allies aren't speaking english is because they don't want to speak to me, which is hindering to the team as a whole.

Analogy and parallels can only be drawn if the CONTEXT is similar or identical. Otherwise it's called comparing apples to oranges. Just as fried noodles and spaghetti are not the same deal even if they both use noodles, the 2 random scenarios of speaking a particular official language or otherwise is not immediately valid just because the scenes both involve the act of speaking. Again, analogies can only be drawn if the situation is comparable, substitute-able, or even identical contextually.

And no, if someone says "soz no English" and you immediately assume they said so because they're some random dickbags wanting to sabotage the communication without any further proof, it's called a negative-bias, where you assume something or someone (and their actions) you can't understand or are not familiar with, to be against your interest by default. Which is an incredibly bad way of looking at things.

Thirdly, just because you might have never encountered someone who just can't speak English, or that they are so bad at it they don't like using it, or whatever personal reasons they may have but is not out to ruin the party, it doesn't mean the circumstance is not valid or present. After all, general statistics tells us that English speakers is only the 3rd largest population despite vast global uses, behind Mandarin and Spanish speakers, it's obviously likely for someone to encounter others even in English speaking countries who can either not or that they are very bad at English (and like wise for other official languages of whatever places that are more diversely populated). And there is nothing wrong with that.

In fact, there is nothing wrong with it if you just don't want to speak English, as long as the premise is not rooted in trying to disrupt the communication. Just as someone being completely silent, muting everyone at the start of the game etc are all valid personal choices (and no one is ever against it if someone were to make the call) if they use alternatives like pings and actually engage in team work, there is nothing to give a shit about whether or not the person behind a monitor really has an A grade on their most recent English/whatever-official-language exam.
